Existing designs of WFL have focused primarily on three key performance indicators (KPIs), namely, model accuracy, convergence speed, and energy efficiency, separately in most cases, as summarized in Table I.
Attempts have been witnessed to improve the training accuracy of WFL, typically by increasing the number of participating usersÂ [11, 12] and/or the size of the datasets involved in trainingÂ [10].
The authors ofÂ [10] andÂ [11] revealed that large datasets or a large number of participating users contribute to the training efficiency of WFL, respectively; i.e., â€œlarger-is-better."
InÂ [12], the impacts of the â€œlater-is-betterâ€ phenomenon, i.e., involving more training data at later stages of WFL, were analyzed quantitatively on the training accuracy, loss, and robustness of WFL.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows.
In SectionÂ II, the system model is described, the convergence upper bound is analyzed, and the new metric is defined. In Section III, the new problem is formulated to jointly optimize the power and bandwidth allocations and its solution is derived. Simulation results are presented in SectionÂ IV, followed by conclusions in SectionÂ V. The notations used are collated in Table II.
